Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Societal Impact, Ethics, and Big-Data-Enabled Social Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This award will support US participation in the Global Science Forum (GSF) of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). GSF provides a venue for mutual consultation among senior science policy officials of OECD member countries. It produces findings on high-priority science-policy issues that require international co-operation, and identifies opportunities for collaboration on major scientific undertakings. This award will support the participation of two PIs in planning meetings with GSF experts for an international conference tentatively entitled "The Ethics of Using New Forms of Data for Social Research." The conference is to be held in Chicago, and it will bring US scientists together with OECD experts to develop an international framework for the ethical use of big data in research. The analysis and application of large datasets, also known as big data research, is an important area of research supported by NSF's Directorate for Social, Behavioral, and Economic Sciences (SBE). The conference will be organized as plenary, breakout and poster sessions. It will bring together scientists, policy makers, industry, funding agencies, and public interest groups who have an interest in addressing the ethical use of big data in the SBE sciences. Big data is growing in importance for many areas critical to society, including health, finance and science. The outputs of this conference will help researchers identify the key issues in research ethics and explore an international framework related to the ethics of the use of big data in research.

Technical Summary

The conference being planned will advance the SBE subfields of Research Ethics and Privacy Protection in Big Data by developing a forward-looking framework on how to overcome the tradeoff between big data and research ethics to effectively pursue the potential of big data without sacrificing privacy rights or violating research ethics. These goals are particularly challenging because satisfying them will require inherently interdisciplinary approaches, and they will require anticipatory approaches (scenario development), which are just starting to be developed. The proposed activities will serve to improve insights and to provide a framework for approaching the reuse of new forms of data. They will inform policy making and scientific practice with regards to data reuse, as well as provide a foundation for conducting ethical analysis of relevant data use scenarios. The proposed effort will result in a framework for internationally acceptable guidelines for the use of big data in SBE research, and it will thereby have profound implications not only for data-related research but also for data-related governance and policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using data to better understand and improve cities is no longer a revolutionary new idea. Cities across the world now release data publicly and use data internally to drive better services, social scientists increasingly use “big” data and computation to study urban environments, and civic hacking groups create data-driven websites and apps to inform and benefit communities. But in many ways, these are just the low-hanging fruit of urban data science, which remains a young field with more promise than results.  The NSF-funded project, “Societal Impact, Ethics, and Big-Data-Enabled Social Sciences,” set out to accomplish two objectives.  The first was to enable participation by U.S. social scientists in an expert group convened by the Organization for Economic and Co-Operation and Development (OECD), to develop and publish an international framework for data ethics related to new forms of data available for social and economic sciences.  The second objective was to present this proposed framework to a broad community of scientists from various disciplines, encouraging feedback and discussion through a workshop hosted by the University of Chicago.

After a series of international workshops involving experts from 11 countries as well as the European Union and OECD, the proposed framework, “Research Ethics and New Forms of Data for Social and Economic Research,” was published in 2016, and is available online.  Leveraging the NSF-funded Urban Sciences Research Coordination Network (US-RCN, NSF Award # 1244749), the project team organized a multi-disciplinary “Convening on Urban Data Science,” inviting US-RCN and many others to submit position papers, which were used to build a multi-track program with some 100 academics, policymakers, and industry experts.  The Convening was jointly sponsored by the University of Chicago’s Harris School of Public Policy, UChicago-Urban network, and the UChicago/Argonne Urban Center for Computation and Data (UrbanCCD).

The convening involved an overview of the OECD framework by Professor Peter Elias (University of Warwick), who chaired the international experts group, and Hallvard Fossheim (University of Bergen), who co-chaired the experts group.  Other plenary presentations included a keynote address by Julia Lane (New York University), and plenary presentations by Charlie Catlett (UrbanCDD director) and Tom Schenk (Chief Data Officer, City of Chicago).

The foremost topic was informed consent in an age of increased data collection, where the public may not always be aware of how their data will be used by governments and researchers. Where the OECD report recommended the use of Ethics Review Boards similar to those seen in medical research. Part of the framework evaluation and discussion was a panel including Lane, Nicole Marwell (UChicago), and Peter Muhlberger (NSF) where alternative structures were discussed such as establishing a Code of Ethics to create research norms for urban science, as well as a commitment to evaluating both the potential benefits and the potential risks of a given research endeavor, with some participants suggesting that such a board should discourage research whose risks outweigh benefits.  Irrespective of mechanisms, there was strong consensus around the importance of proactive privacy protections and engaging the public regarding privacy and risks.

Breakout sessions were more methods-focused, examining how different public data sources and techniques such as GIS mapping could help answer important questions about cities. For instance, Jennifer Doleac (University of Virginia) presented a study on using data audio sensors that detect and locate gunfire, to assess whether juvenile curfews affect street crime. A project called Micro-Array of Things, run by University of Chicago Medicine’s Stacy Tessler Lindau, Douglas Pancoast (School of the Art Institute of Chicago), and Paloma Gonzalez Rojas (MIT), discussed their use of inexpensive sensors to observe, in a privacy-preserving fashion, how families use an open free food pantry in the children’s hospital.

As with the US-RCN, the Convening was meant not only to discuss the proposed OECD framework but to inspire and highlight collaborations that cross traditional disciplinary lines and build new knowledge and research out of existing or imminent data and technology.
